awd_titl_txt: EDGE: Enabling functional genomics in monkeyflowers (Mimulus)
awd_abstract_narration:
A fundamental goal in biology is to understand the genes and developmental processes that affect ecological success and adaptation of organisms in natural environments. Historically, a mechanistic understanding of ecologically important phenotypes has been limited to a small number of genes in very few model organisms. The research will improve genetic tools in the wildflower genus Mimulus (monkeyflowers), a system that exhibits rich diversity in form, physiology, and life history. By connecting this diversity with functional genetic analysis and field experiments, the research will enable molecular genetic investigations of previously unexplored of phenotypic variation. With the tools proposed here, the growing Mimulus scientific community will be in an excellent position to identify the causal genetic mechanisms underlying ecologically important traits. The research will provide hands-on learning opportunities for two different undergraduate laboratory courses taught at University of Georgia and University of California, Riverside. In addition, the research will offer training experiences for local high school teachers in Georgia to develop and refine lab activities for dissemination in the high school classroom. Furthermore, the plant materials generated in this research will be incorporated into live plant outreach activities at the University of Connecticut for student and public education. Finally, the actives will be broadly disseminated via the Plant Biology section on the "Learn.Genetics" website as online educational resources.

Identifying the genetic and developmental determinants of natural phenotypic variation is fundamentally important for understanding organismal biology and the processes that generate biodiversity. The genus Mimulus is an exceptionally diverse group of approximately 200 wildflower species with abundant natural populations that is ideally suited for linking naturally occurring genotypes to their ecologically important phenotypes. The research will enable Mimulus as a powerful new model for ecological functional genomics and plant developmental genetics. The specific scientific objectives are as follows: 1) Optimize genetic transformation protocols in seven Mimulus species that are actively studied by many researchers and represent a wide range of phylogenetic diversity. 2) Generate large-scale chemical and transposon insertion mutant libraries for three of the most actively studied species. Additionally, a major goal of the research is to enable Mimulus researchers to take full advantage of the newly developed functional genomics protocols and resources in their own labs. This project includes an annual, weeklong summer lab short course that will rotate between the University of Connecticut and the University of Georgia. The project will also include a website to disseminate detailed instructions and video tutorials of protocols, as well as a searchable database with information on plant lines, seed stocks, and other important tools generated from this work.

This award was co-funded by funds from Enabling Discovery through GEnomic Tools (EDGE) Program and the Evolutionary Process Program within the Division of Environmental Biology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Science:

Identifying the genetic and developmental basis of ecologically important traits is fundamentally important for understanding adaptive evolution and the origin of biological diversity. Historically, progress toward a mechanistic understanding of ecologically relevant phenotypes has been slow because technical limitations have restricted study to only a small number of model organisms. Now, for the first time, the tools of functional genomics allow researchers to pursue direct links between particular genes and key phenotypes in a variety of non-model species. Ideally suited for such studies are species that are rich in ecologically interesting traits and tractable for experimentation. The wildflower genus Mimulus (monkeyflowers) is one such system that combines extraordinary diversity in morphology, physiology, and life history with the ability to conduct genetic analyses and field experiments. This EDGE research has made significant strides toward enabling Mimulus as a powerful model for ecological functional genomics and plant developmental genetics.

One major outcome of this project has been the optimization of a tissue-culture-based protocol to genetically transform two of the most actively studied species of Mimulus, M. guttatus and M. nasutus. We rigorously evaluated of the success and efficiency of this protocol, testing various conditions for generating healthy callus tissue and performing reliable transformation with Agrobacterium (e.g., varying strains, selection agents, and antibiotics). The result is an optimized protocol that consistently produces healthy callus and transgenic Mimulus plants. This protocol is now routine in the Sweigart lab and has been disseminated to the wider Mimulus community through short-course trainings and online notebooks.

Another outcome of this funding has been the optimization of the floral spray/infiltration protocol for generating stable transgenic lines in multiple Mimulus species, including M. parishii, M. cardinalis, M. guttatus, M. luteus, and M. cupreus. Notably, it was discovered that the selfing species M. parishii is particularly amenable to floral spray/infiltration based transformation. The transformation efficiency of this species is so high that it was used as the host background for the random activation-tagging mutagenesis experiment, where thousands of transgenic lines were generated, each with a strong, constitutive promoter (the CaMV 35S promoter) inserted in a random genomic location. Many interesting mutant phenotypes were recovered from these activation-tagging lines.

Together, these projects have significantly improved functional tools in Mimulus, enabling molecular genetic investigations of previously unexplored facets of phenotypic variation. With these tools in place, the Mimulus community is now making tremendous progress toward identifying the causal variants and developmental mechanisms of many ecologically important traits.

Education:

A major goal of this EDGE grant has been to ensure the broad and timely dissemination of our protocols, with particular emphasis on training the next generation of Mimulus researchers. Toward this aim, we proposed to implement three weeklong summer courses to train researchers to use our protocols in their own labs. We successfully completed all three of these short-courses. The first was held at UConn in June of 2019 and served 10 participants from nine labs at nine universities. The second course was held at UConn in August 2022 and served 11 participants from 8 labs at 8 universities. The third course was held at UGA in May 2023 and served 10 participants from nine labs at eight universities. Participants in these courses spanned all career levels, including incoming and current graduate students, postdocs, and faculty. Instructors covered a wide range of topics, including the biology of plant transformation, approaches for gene knockdown/knockout and overexpression, plasmid design and construction, transient gene expression assays, stable transformation of Mimulus using floral spray/infiltration and tissue-culture based protocols, transgenic screens, Agrobacterium biology, gene editing technologies, and stewardship. Participants left these workshops with detailed lab protocols and are now equipped to perform transformation experiments in their own labs.

To promote broad dissemination of our research beyond the participants of the short course, we created a user-friendly website, “MimuBase” (mimubase.org), which is hosted at a high-performance cluster administered by the UConn Computational Biology Core. We have continued to develop the Mimubase website and it is now operating as a vital resource for our community. This website includes genomic and marker data, strain information (including extensive information on wild collections), meeting announcements, and protocols.

During three summers of this grant, the Sweigart lab hosted local K-12 teachers. In collaboration with these teachers, we have developed hands-on lab activities using Mimulus to teach concepts in genetics and evolution to middle and high school biology students. Finally, this funding has provided training and mentoring to 13 undergraduate students, 8 graduate students, 1 postbac researcher, and 2 postdoctoral researchers at UGA and UConn.
